text: okay uh we have a Management console where you can which is essentially a user interface for you to uh use the
service you can create uh transcoding jobs you can create transcoding presets
you can uh test them out without writing any code and then typically when you want to go off and integrate the service
into a production environment you would use the Amazon elastic transcoder API
and you would interface with that API through SD software development kits that we make available to you we provide
a set of predefined transcoding presets for common output formats and common devices so for instance if you wanted to
transcode content for an iPad or for an iPhone there's a preset that does that you don't need to think about what the
right transcoding settings are for that the service is designed to be
scalable so we designed it from the ground up to actually scale using the uh Amazon uh web services best practices
for building scalable Services we also rely on a number of other Amazon web
services uh because we we don't believe in Reinventing the wheel um and uh it
makes sense for us to actually leverage uh other services uh such as the simple workflow service for instance uh and
Dynamo DB uh to actually make our service work we also offer transcoding pipelines
that enable you to organize your jobs and actually process them in parallel and we talk a little bit more about that
later but the idea is that that gives you a scalable way to organize your
workflows thirdly we're coste effective so like other Amazon web services there are no minimums there's no commitments
and we have a very simple pricing structure which I'll go into in a little bit more detail but fundamentally it's
per minute pricing per minute based on the duration of your content finally we're a managed service
so we manage the Codex we manage the processing we manage the line licensing all of that is is part of the actual
service offering so you're not actually having to manage scalability you're not having to manage updating codec you're
not having to manage how and and where you actually process your um uh your
assets the service takes care of that for you some reasons why customers actually
use Amazon elastic transcoder first of all they don't need to uh manage the the volume of the of
their transcoding um there's an increasing amount of content that's out there the idea is that as a customer you
just give us that content in the form of transcoding jobs we transcode it for you uh whether you have a large amount or a
small amount it doesn't matter and you don't need to worry about that the second point is that you don't need to
worry about building uh for uh Peak uh usage so if you have uh a situation
where on a weekly or a monthly basis you get a large amount of a large volume of
content that needs to get transcoded traditionally you might need to provision to actually handle that Peak
load and and the that Peak capacity is sitting idle the rest of the time with
um the the cloud-based service you you don't need to manage that you don't need to build for that you just it's just
there and it scales as you require it to scale thirdly you don't need to worry about format support uh there's
obviously an increasing number of output formats and and devices that need to be supported that's part of the the value
that Amazon transcoder brings to you the ability to support the different formats and keep current with the various output
formats that are that are popular let's look at a couple of customers in fact three um grammar film
is a uh is an independent uh Film Production Company uh one of the first customers of uh the the service and one
of the things that they really liked is the Simplicity of using it and integrating it into their workflow
the customer is El um specifically a uh project called clinical key uh which is
a website for clinici that provides them with uh with information and they use it to transcode videos about uh clinical
procedures and uh things like sleep studies and so on uh so they actually have a large amount of content um that
needed to get transcoded and then they have regular content on a on a frequent basis that needs to uh that needs to get
transcoded to update the content on the website and you know one of the things that they really liked about it was the
fact that um the service would just satisfy the transcoding requirements they had um and that it was easy for
them to
integrate another example is a fairly unique online video platform called
benchly and uh benchly is an online video platform for um the live Sciences
so if you're a live scientist and you have a specific lab procedure that you want to share with other life scientists
either within your own um organization or externally uh benchly is an online
video platform that lets you do that uh and again they're they're using the service because they have very uh they
have spiky um transcoding requirements they have the requirement to support many different output formats and they
wanted something that was inexpensive and easy for them to
integrate so let's look at some of the key features of Amazon elastic transcoder I mentioned transcoding
pipelines earlier uh transcoding pipelines are a way for you to uh have
multiple transcoding jobs running at the same time um it they're a way for you to
organize your transcoding jobs as well so um that there are many ways that you
can actually use transcoding pipelines an example would be um a customer might want to say I have a transcoding
pipeline for high priority uh content maybe I'm a news organizer ation and I always want to keep one of my
transcoding pipelines free from jobs and just use that as I uh get my high
priority content in um and then use my other transcoding pipelines for the for
the the regular work uh another way to use transcoding pipelines might be I will send all of my lower resolution job
through one transcoding pipeline because typically those would take um a shorter amount of time to transcode um and so
that that means that my lower resolution files would always come out first so there's many ways to use transcoding
pipelines we don't enforce them in any particular way they're really there as a construct for you to use to facilitate
various workflows that you might uh wish to implement then we have transcoding presets I already mentioned that we have
predefined ones for popular output devices we also have custom presets that are available to you within your AWS
account within a uh specific uh AWS region so you can create custom presets
for maybe a specific uh Web format maybe you have a specific size of of uh video
that's required for your web player or perhaps you have tuned um output for a
specific device so the custom presets would be a way for you to do that and I'll show you an example of that a
little bit later we offer monitoring and management uh both through the the console the AWS
Management console as well as the the API of the service
itself we also provide provide notifications of uh transcoding activity and job activity through the AWS SNS or
simple notification service so another example of where we've built on top of other existing AWS services so with SNS
you actually create a a topic it's a publish And subscribe mechanism so you create a topic and Amazon elastic
transcoder will publish notifications to that topic and you can have either one topic or multiple topics uh it's it's
very configurable and that's a way that enables you to be notified on specific conditions for instance whether a job
has started to uh transcode whether a job has finished processing whether there's any error or warning conditions
and it means that you don't actually need to pull the API um on a on a regular basis to find out what's going
on you can just get that information pushed to you which is a much more efficient way of
operating in terms of format support and one of the new features is that we've added to our list of um out put formats
that we that we support uh initially when we launched we supported uh h264
video AAC audio in an mp4 um container which is uh by far the most common
format that you tend to find out there it's playable on on devices and browsers we've added uh h264 video AAC audio in
an EG 2 transport stream container um and that's useful um as it stands for
broadcast applications but it also uh is the founder ation for uh doing things
like uh HTTP uh live streaming or hls support and we've also added the Google
webm format so that's vp8 uh video uh vbis audio in a webm uh
container then we've added uh support for segmenting um hls files so you can
create a an hls file set uh and we will segment that for you and create the
playlist and put that into uh into your S3 buckets uh in a in a specific folder
structure and I'll show you a demo of that later on and what that lets you do is to immediately uh take advantage of
adaptive streaming technologies that are built into hls compatible players um
some examples of those would be iOS devices uh quick time on the Mac and then also um various um other devices
like some and later versions of Android Kindle Fire uh the Roku set toop box
uh and then also uh web players like the JW player for instance will um handle hls uh content very
nicely we're available in multiple regions um and the best practice is to
uh do the transcoding work where your content is stored so let's say uh you're
in the um uh you're you're in the uh uh one of the you in the US west region um
Oregon um you and you store your content there it would make sense for you to do the transcoding there because that way
you're not moving content around unnecessarily similarly if you also have content stored in the uh Us North
Virginia region then do your transcoding there because you're not moving content around and finally uh as I mentioned we
have the console access as well as the API um access uh and then we provide
sdks for java.net nodejs PHP Python and Ruby and these are the standard AWS SDK
so if you download the latest version I believe it's 1.4.4 do2 uh that will have
uh full support for all of the new features of Amazon elastic
transcoder here's a block diagram of the service you can see the transcoding pipelines that I mentioned uh stacked in
the middle the idea is that fundamentally a transcoding pipeline connects an input S3 bucket to an output
S3 bucket they could be the same buckets uh it's really up to you how you how you configure that the idea is that each
pipeline is a que transcoding Jobs live in that transcoding pipeline or Q which
you can see at the bottom and each transcoding pipeline uh sorry each transcoding job has an S3 object and a
preset associated with it and that's what the transcoding job actually
is in terms of pricing um I have a very tiny preview on my screen so this is
barely legible for me but is hopefully more legible for you there a table of our current pricing which is also um
published on our website it's it's a simple permanent pricing there's no commitment standard
definition content um is half the price of high definition content and standard
definition content starts at 1.5 us cents per minute uh in the US East and
US West Oregon Region High Definition for us is is uh defined in in typical uh
in a typical web fashion as anything that's 720p or above in terms of
resolution we have a free tier and it's a monthly free tier uh so every month you can transcode up to 20 minutes of
standard definition or 10 minutes of high definition content um per month and
you know you can do that in month one and then next month you can you can do the same thing and it'll be free that's a great way to test the service it's a
great way to test different trans coding presets uh figure out if you have a if you have a specific format and you want
to make sure that that works well and gives you what you expect it's a great way to test it without incurring any
costs we have a policy of forgiving um failed jobs so if you have a job and it
fails um get back to customer service and um you know we'll we'll forgive you for that um we also don't have any data
transfer charges within a region so that means that if you're transcoding within the same region is where your your
content is stored the uh there's no we don't charge you for transferring your
content from S3 into the elastic transcoder

so the um there's a couple of things to say there so the first is that um there is a limit of four pipelines per AWS
account um if you um if that needs to get increased then um you can use the uh
the the contact link on our detail page in FAQ um to get in touch with us and we
can discuss increasing that a lot of time we hear customers um designing systems such that they have one input
bucket for they have a separate input bucket for each of their own customers in S3 that tends to be a PO design
practice just because there are limits on the number of input buckets you can have in S3 um and so you you you're kind
of designing your system um and and will ultimately run up against that limit so
a better thing to do is to use the the concept of folders um which is using
that forward slash as part of the object name um and then essentially create a file system within S3 and that means
that uh you don't need to have a single uh bucket per per customer and therefore
you don't need to have multiple pipelines per customer so pipelines tend to be a much better way of organizing
